reviews.review_title: An Experience at Les Palmiers: A Study in Contrasts
reviews.positive_text:
Title: An Experience at Les Palmiers: A Study in Contrasts

Review:
During my recent sojourn in Agadir, I selected Hotel Les Palmiers as my abode, lured primarily by its affordable pricing and the understanding that it bore a modest three-star rating. My expectations were, as a result, tempered, calibrated to the promises that such an establishment inherently makes. Yet, what unfolded was a tableau of contrasts that warrants a reflective exploration.

On arrival, one is met with the façade of Les Palmiers, which, despite its simplicity, retains a certain charm emblematic of its regional character. The lobby, though unpretentious, is punctuated by a warmth and earnestness exuded by the staff. They navigate the art of hospitality with a congeniality that speaks to the heart more profoundly than opulent trimmings could achieve.

The accommodations, predictably Spartan, adhered to the austerity of a thrifty traveler’s expectations. A bed, functional and firm; a window, welcoming the golden Moroccan sun; each element of the room curates a symphony of subtlety, a hymn to minimalism. However, it is within the confines of the en-suite bathroom that a philosophical chasm manifests—a testament to neglect standing in stark opposition to the remainder of the hotel’s offerings.

The lavatory, the crucible of personal sanitation and solace, was in a state of disrepair that transcended mere imperfection. It was, quite candidly, in a deplorable condition. The surfaces, etched with the patina of erstwhile use and bearing an odious scent, demanded from me a more imaginative form of ablution rather than endure its purported utility. It is here that I implore the proprietors: a fresh coat of paint is not merely cosmetic; it is an act of respect, an acknowledgement of the sanctity of cleanliness—a notion surely not lost even on the most budget-conscious travelers.
reviews.negative_text:
In the realm of hospitality, the traveler perpetually engages in a tacit dialogue with their temporary abode, seeking refuge not merely in four walls but within the broader context of comfort, cleanliness, and care. It was within this framework of anticipation that I approached Hotel Les Palmiers in Agadir, only to be met with a revealing study in the discordance between expectation and reality.

As a venue that wears the badge of a three-star rating, Les Palmiers subtly implies a promise of adequacy—a promise that, unfortunately, falters significantly within its crucial facilities. Whilst the economic allure of the establishment cannot be overstated, the state of its bathroom facilities stands in stark opposition to even the most forgiving of standards.

Upon crossing the unfortunate threshold of the bathroom, I was greeted not with the sterile embrace of cleanliness but with a veritable archaeology of neglect. The surfaces bore witness to times unremembered, draped in a film of residue that resisted the most basic of hygienic principles. The tiles, worn and discoloring, suggested a history longing to be washed away, or at very least, refreshed by a much-needed coat of paint.

To abstain from utilizing such a pivotal amenity as the shower is an action not taken lightly, yet I found myself committed to this course by necessity rather than preference. The lack of remedial attention to these facilities speaks volumes, for it is in such spaces that a hotel's reverence for its guests is most earnestly communicated.

The olfactory discomfort, mingling with a visual narrative of dilapidation, paints an indelible image that no traveler should be forced to endure. This oversight in maintenance pushes even the most frugal of accommodations beyond the threshold of acceptability, challenging the very essence of its categorization as a haven for rest.

reviews.positive_text: The bed was fine, only had a thick blanket but I felt a bit sick/cold that night so this was no problem. But in hot days when you're not feeling cold you would have to sleep without one.
reviews.negative_text:
The shower/bath was just gross, it looked like one straight out of a horror movie. We booked two rooms and in one of them the whole bathroom floor was wet and smelled very bad so we didn't use this one. Also there were no towels so we had to use our beach towels to dry off after showering.

Also on booking.com it says the room is for 1 person with only 1 bed so we booked two rooms and paid for two. When we arrived we saw that each room has 2 beds, I asked the guy behind the desk if we could only rent 1 rooms since we were with two. He quickly said "it doesn't matter its the same price", which sounds very weird considering they would have to clean two rooms instead of one. So either they don't clean at all or he lied into my face?

reviews.positive_text: Upon arrival, we were warmly welcomed by the reception staff, who were friendly and helpful — one of the few positive aspects of our stay.
reviews.negative_text:
Unfortunately, the condition of the rooms was disappointing and in urgent need of renovation. The furniture was outdated, and there was a strong unpleasant smell in the room, likely due to mold or humidity in the bathroom. Cleanliness was lacking — there was no toilet paper, no hand soap, no shampoo, and only one towel provided. These are basic essentials that should be available in any hotel, even a basic 2-star one.

Another major downside was the lack of soundproofing. Street noise and people passing by made it very difficult to get a good night’s sleep.

Positives:

Friendly and welcoming reception staff.

Good location, about 900 meters from the beach, and close to local markets and a public park.

Overall Rating:

Rooms: ⭐ 1/5 — Dirty, outdated, and missing essentials.

Service: ⭐ 1/5 — Very limited amenities.

Location: ⭐ 4/5 — Convenient and central.

Unfortunately, I wouldn’t recommend this hotel unless it's a last-minute or very short stay option.

reviews.positive_text: That I didn't stay here for more than one night. That the weather outside was nice. That no earthquake struck while I was sleeping. That a stay here has helped keep me humble.
reviews.negative_text:
The flaking paint in the bathroom, all three of it's ugly colours, reminded me of vomit. Even the cobwebs had cobwebs, that's how long it's been since the corners had been swept.  I was worried some strange semi-tropical critter was going to crawl out from beneath my bed and malaria zombify me. My bed only had a bottom sheet and a dark brown blanket that could have camouflaged any sort of laboratory science manufactured mutation. 

The bathtub looked like a sarcophagus, and smelled like its last occupant had been scraped out of it with a putty knife and Comet, a porcelain cleaner. I had to keep the door shut to block out the stink of bleach and mummies. The towel they game me was like cardboard, with orange speckles all over it, maybe rust spots, or worse.

I think I was even overcharged at check in. When I mentioned I might stay more than one night, the ghoul at the front desk replied "IF there are any rooms available".  Maybe there was a vampire convention in town?

This is not a place even for budget travelers, but for old dying men with last stage emphysema, hacking out a lung in the lobby like stuttering jack-hammers, whispering in semi silent conversation - in between consecutive Gauloises - with other down-and-outers. I've seen more attractive places on skid row. And it's not that this was a budget place. I've stayed in several residences in Morocco at this price and never seen this much sad neglect.  

Stay far away from this place.

reviews.review_title: An Experience at Les Palmiers: A Study in Contrasts
reviews.positive_text:
Title: An Experience at Les Palmiers: A Study in Contrasts

Review:
During my recent sojourn in Agadir, I selected Hotel Les Palmiers as my abode, lured primarily by its affordable pricing and the understanding that it bore a modest three-star rating. My expectations were, as a result, tempered, calibrated to the promises that such an establishment inherently makes. Yet, what unfolded was a tableau of contrasts that warrants a reflective exploration.

On arrival, one is met with the façade of Les Palmiers, which, despite its simplicity, retains a certain charm emblematic of its regional character. The lobby, though unpretentious, is punctuated by a warmth and earnestness exuded by the staff. They navigate the art of hospitality with a congeniality that speaks to the heart more profoundly than opulent trimmings could achieve.

The accommodations, predictably Spartan, adhered to the austerity of a thrifty traveler’s expectations. A bed, functional and firm; a window, welcoming the golden Moroccan sun; each element of the room curates a symphony of subtlety, a hymn to minimalism. However, it is within the confines of the en-suite bathroom that a philosophical chasm manifests—a testament to neglect standing in stark opposition to the remainder of the hotel’s offerings.

The lavatory, the crucible of personal sanitation and solace, was in a state of disrepair that transcended mere imperfection. It was, quite candidly, in a deplorable condition. The surfaces, etched with the patina of erstwhile use and bearing an odious scent, demanded from me a more imaginative form of ablution rather than endure its purported utility. It is here that I implore the proprietors: a fresh coat of paint is not merely cosmetic; it is an act of respect, an acknowledgement of the sanctity of cleanliness—a notion surely not lost even on the most budget-conscious travelers.
reviews.negative_text:
In the realm of hospitality, the traveler perpetually engages in a tacit dialogue with their temporary abode, seeking refuge not merely in four walls but within the broader context of comfort, cleanliness, and care. It was within this framework of anticipation that I approached Hotel Les Palmiers in Agadir, only to be met with a revealing study in the discordance between expectation and reality.

As a venue that wears the badge of a three-star rating, Les Palmiers subtly implies a promise of adequacy—a promise that, unfortunately, falters significantly within its crucial facilities. Whilst the economic allure of the establishment cannot be overstated, the state of its bathroom facilities stands in stark opposition to even the most forgiving of standards.

Upon crossing the unfortunate threshold of the bathroom, I was greeted not with the sterile embrace of cleanliness but with a veritable archaeology of neglect. The surfaces bore witness to times unremembered, draped in a film of residue that resisted the most basic of hygienic principles. The tiles, worn and discoloring, suggested a history longing to be washed away, or at very least, refreshed by a much-needed coat of paint.

To abstain from utilizing such a pivotal amenity as the shower is an action not taken lightly, yet I found myself committed to this course by necessity rather than preference. The lack of remedial attention to these facilities speaks volumes, for it is in such spaces that a hotel's reverence for its guests is most earnestly communicated.

The olfactory discomfort, mingling with a visual narrative of dilapidation, paints an indelible image that no traveler should be forced to endure. This oversight in maintenance pushes even the most frugal of accommodations beyond the threshold of acceptability, challenging the very essence of its categorization as a haven for rest.

Solo usé mi propia conexión a internet. La habitación no está limpia y, durante mi estancia, no la limpiaron en absoluto. Imagínense nueve días sin servicio de limpieza. Además, lo que más molesta a los huéspedes es la camarera. Temprano por la mañana, hace mucho ruido, azota las puertas de las habitaciones y arrastra las sillas. Lamentablemente, no respeta la comodidad de los huéspedes. Habla muy alto por teléfono, sin consideración alguna. El problema es que lo hace todos los días. El hotel no merece ni 3 puntos, pero le di 8 para no contribuir a su declive. Sin embargo, hay que tener en cuenta la comodidad de los huéspedes y la resolución de problemas del hotel

reviews.review_title: Ich habe noch nie in so einem schlechten, ekligen Hotel übernachtet. Ich würde absolut abraten hier zu übernachten.
reviews.positive_text: Zentrale Lage. Parken vor dem Haus kostenlos möglich. Es gibt ein kleines Frühstücksrestaurant.
reviews.negative_text:
Das Bad war kaputt und seit langem nicht gereinigt. Auf dem Boden lagen viele lange Haare herum und das Waschbecken war voll mit orangenen Dreckflecken (siehe Bilder in der Beschreibung). Außerdem hing das Waschbecken von der Wand weg und der Abfluss war undicht, sodass das Wasser aus dem Waschbecken über den Boden gelaufen ist und in der Dusche versickert ist. Beim Händewaschen bekommt man also nasse Füße und eine nasse Hose.  
Seife war nicht da. Die Handtücher haben nicht den Eindruck gemacht als seien sie frisch. Ich habe mich geekelt und daher mein eigenes benutzen müssen. 
Auch bei den Betten konnte ich nicht sagen, ob sie frisch bezogen waren.
Duschwasser kommt nur lauwarm, ich hatte Sorge vor Legionellen.

reviews.review_title: Günstiges Hotel aber man muss teilweise auf absolute Basics verzichten.
reviews.positive_text: Es ist relativ günstig und zentral. Parken vor dem Haus an der Straße gratis möglich.
reviews.negative_text:
Es gab keine Seife im Hotel und ich war mir nicht sicher, ob alles frisch gewaschen war oder noch vom Gast zuvor war. Eines der Kopfkissen war leicht feucht, wie durchgeschwitzt als ich ankam.
Bei Rückfrage an der Rezeption nach Seife wurde ich an den Laden nebenan verwiesen, wo ich ein Stück Seife für 8 Dirham gekauft habe.

Die Möbel sind absolut heruntergekommen und nur noch funktional aber nicht mehr schön.

reviews.review_title: Por Booking no te dan buena habitación
reviews.positive_text: La ubicación
reviews.negative_text: Me cobró más de lo que la página de Booking me decía. El precio real de la habitación es mas alto que el de Booking por ello creo que me dieron la peor habitación, luces que no funcionan, el baño huele desagradable y está desconchado por todas partes. Para que salga el agua ♨️ se hace eterno y presión del agua nefasta. La distribución d los enchufes es difícil de entender y la bañera y el lavabo estaban atascados.

reviews.review_title: Hotel en ruinas. No cumple condiciones de higiene.
reviews.positive_text: Nada de nada. El personal muy agresivo, sin ningún tipo de empatia hacia turistas. Las habitaciones estan en ruinas. La bañera con desconchones y sucia, cortinas descolgadas y manchadas, el suelo con capas de basura, etc.
reviews.negative_text:
Lo peor de todo es que ademas del estado tan ruinoso del hotel está todo muy sucio, los vasos en el aseo con costras de suciedad, la bañera asquerosa, el suelo lleno de basura, las cortinas manchadas, olor fortísimo  a orin de gato, etc. 
El personal del hotel es muy agresivo, sin empatia hacia turistas. En el momento del check-in nos dice el recepcionista que ya era tarde y que nuestra reserva está cancelada, tuve que mostrarle el chat en Booking con la confirmación del hotel de la hora de entrada para que nos diera una habitación, de lo contrario nos hubiera dejado en la calle.

reviews.positive_text:
Ich hatte woanders gefrühstückt. Die Lage des Hotels ist gut. Zimmer einigermaßen akzeptabel und auch relativ ruhig. Was verbessert werden könnte, ist die Internetverbindung und der Zimmerdienst. Auch nach 7 Tagen Aufenthalt habe ich keine Putzfrau gesehen oder bemerkt.
Die Hotelzahlung selbst sollte besser über Booking.com abgewickelt werden. Vor Ort habe ich ca. 10 % mehr gezahlt als prospektiert, was mich nicht unbedingt amused gemacht hat.
reviews.negative_text: bereits alles Wesentliche erzählt.

reviews.positive_text: Sehr freundliches Personal. Das Zimmer war halt nur zum übernachten gedacht und deshalb stellten wir auch keine großen Ansprüche. Allerdings sollten die Badewannen mal gewechselt werden wenn mal etwas Geld übrig bleibt. Bei den Zimmerpreisen kann und sollte man nicht mehr komfor verlangen. Schließlich wurden die Zimmer täglich gereinigt und das Personal muss auch bezahlt werden. Für uns war es ausreichend für die kleine Geldbörse. Dankeschön an das Personal 👍😊
